An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
Does the concept of a/an A-module need to be defined for a definition of a/an Rank of an A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an A-module is foundational for defining the rank of an A-module. The rank of an A-module, as defined, relies on the structure of the A-module to determine the maximum number of linearly independent elements it can contain. Without the definition of an A-module, which establishes how elements of the module interact with elements of the ring A, it would be impossible to apply concepts like linear independence or exterior multiplication, which are crucial for determining the rank. Therefore, the definition of an A-module is necessary to provide the context and structure within which the rank of an A-module is defined and understood.
